questions.text: Which of the following is used as nail lacquer for fungal infections?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Terbinafine Out of all the drugs, Terbinafine is used as Nail lacquer for fungal infection. Terbinafine is a commonly used drug for the treatment of dermatophytosis. Class : Allylamines and may be used topically or orally. MOA: Terbinafine inhibits lanosterol synthesis by inhibiting the enzyme squalene epoxidase. This drug tends to accumulate in the skin and its appendages, and its side effects are mild by the topical route.

Highyeild:

Important antifungals mechanism of action: Class of drug Mechanism of action Examples Allyl amines Inhibits lanosterol synthesis by inhibiting squalene epoxidase Terbinafine Antimetabolite Inhibits nucleic acid synthesis Flucytosine Azoles Inhibits ergosterol synthesis by inhibiting 14-alpha-demethylase Ketoconazole Polyenes Disrupts cell membrane integrity Amphotericin B Griseofulvin Act on mitotic spindle

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Fluconazole: It is commonly used to treat yeast infections. Option B. Nystatin: It is often used to treat oral and intestinal fungal infections. Option C. Itraconazole : It is used to treat a variety of systemic fungal infections, but it is not typically used for nail infections.

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon is shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isomorphic phenomenon This picture shows the appearance of new skin lesions on previously unaffected skin secondary to trauma. This phenomenon is termed the isomorphic (from Greek, “equal shape”) phenomenon or Koebner phenomenon.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Reverse isomorphic: It is the disappearance of a skin lesion after trauma to the area (Eg: Granuloma annulare) Option C. Gottron’s papule: This d, erythematous to violaceous papules and plaques found over bony prominences, particularly the metacarpophalangeal joints, the proximal interphalangeal joints, and/or the distal interphalangeal joints which are characteristic feature seen in dermatomyositis. Option D. Nikolsky sign : Can be shown in patients with active blistering. Firm sliding pressure with a finger separates normal-appearing epidermis, producing an erosion (eg pemphigus vulgaris)

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DLE The above-mentioned picture shows scaly discoid like plaque over face with pigmentary changes and atrophy which may be suggestive of DLE Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) is the most common chronic form of cutaneous lupus.

Highyeild:

Discoid lupus erythematosus It is the most common form of cutaneous lupus - a sub-type of chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus . It is characterized by persistent scaly plaques on the scalp, face, and ears which subsequently can progress to scarring, atrophy, depigmentation, and permanent hair loss in affected hair-bearing areas. Age: More common in middle-aged women Cause: Genetic predisposition: HLA-DQA1 and DRB1 Smoking UV radiation Features: DLE can be localised (80%) or generalized (20%) Initial dry red patches evolve to form red plaques with adherent scale: Discoid like plaques Follicular hyperkeratosis is common, give rise to carpet tack sign As DLE progresses, Atrophic scarring and scarring alopecia is common which is associated with hyper-and hypo-pigment are changed. Site: Typically nose, cheeks, ear lobes, and conchal bowl (Shuster sign). Diagnosis: Skin biopsy Treatment: Careful year-round sun protection Vitamin D supplements Smoking cessation

Option C . Rosaceae: It is a chronic inflammatory skin condition predominantly affecting the central face characterized by persistent facial redness. It typically has a relapsing and remitting course, with symptoms controlled by lifestyle measures, general skin care, medications, and procedural interventions. Option D. questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with grouped vesicles over his lips as shown in image. Diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes labialis The given clinical picture is of Herpes labialis. aka Cold sores/ Fever blister Caused by HSV-1 Site: Lip margin Characteristics: Fluid-filled vesicle s May be painful just at the onset of pain may last for a few days. Itching or burning precedes by an hour or two the development of small closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base. Recurrences tend to be in the same region , but not always on the identical site. Fever, pain, and lymphangitis is may be present Treatment: Mild or infrequent herpes labialis may need no treatment. Severe or troublesome recurrence: Acyclovir, Valacyclovir, or Famciclovir.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of papular lesions over the extremities. On examination, the lesions were soft and non-tender. An image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable diagnosis of this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Common warts The given clinical scenario and a picture showing round, raised lesion having a dry and rough surface which is non-tender is of Common warts. Warts: Cause: HPV infection- DNA virus Warts can be classified as Features of common warts: cauliflower-like papules with a rough, papillomatous and hyperkeratotic surface Size: 1mm to 1cm or more Solitary or multiple Site: knees, backs of fingers or toes, and around the nails (periungual). Treatment of HPV infection: Topical lactic acid, salicylic acid Electrocautery Cryotherapy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Condyloma lata: It refers to a benign and painless cutaneous manifestation of secondary syphilis. They are skin-colored or hypopigmented growths characterized by gray to white lesions, typically located in the genital area or around the mouth. Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: It is a common viral skin infection caused by the pox virus which often occurs during childhood that causes localized clusters of umbilicated epidermal papules. Option C . Condyloma accuminata: These are anogenital warts. They are usually sexually transmitted.
